title: Kolkata Weather LATEST update: Heavy rain alert issued for THESE places; how long will it rain? Check forecast - Asianet Newsable
article_text:
Image Credit : Getty

Heavy to very heavy rainfall is expected in the western districts of South Bengal today. Very heavy rainfall is possible in Kalimpong in North Bengal. Rainfall will decrease from tomorrow. Thunderstorms and rain are likely in western districts on Thursday. Scattered thunderstorms and rain will continue. Scattered heavy rain is forecast for North Bengal today and tomorrow. Heavy rainfall will increase again from Sunday.

title: IMD issues orange alert for heavy rainfall in MP, Chhattisgarh, Vidarbha. - en.etemaaddaily.com
article_text: India Meteorological Department (IMD) has issued an orange alert for heavy rainfall accompanied by thunderstorms over Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh and Vidarbha for the next two days. The weather agency has forecast heavy to moderate rainfall over the Northern and Eastern parts of the country. These include Jammu-Kashmir, Punjab, Haryana, Chandigarh, Himachal Pradesh and East Uttar Pradesh today, while East Rajasthan and Uttarakhand till the 15th of this month. Over Northeast India, Assam,Meghalaya, Nagaland, Manipur, Mizoram, and Tripura are likely to witness similar weather conditions during the next 6 days. The IMD has forecast heavy rainfall conditions over Kerala and Coastal Karnataka today.

title: Goods Train Derails After Flash Floods Damage Track In J&K‚Äôs Kathua - Daily Excelsior
article_text:
JAMMU, Jul 10: A goods train on its way to Punjab from Jammu derailed near the Lakhanpur area of Kathua district in Jammu and Kashmir. The incident occurred after incessant rains triggered a flash flood in the area, damaging the railway track, officials said on Thursday.

Travel packages to Jammu

Railway officials reached the spot immediately, and rescue work is underway to restore rail traffic on the affected track, the officials said.

NewsTrendingTrending In IndiaAs heavy rain batters Delhi-NCR, videos of severe waterlogging, submerged vehicles in Gurgaon go viral
As heavy rain batters Delhi-NCR, videos of severe waterlogging, submerged vehicles in Gurgaon go viral
Several videos from Gurgaon's Golf Course Road and other areas show commuters struggling as water levels rise.
By: Trends Desk
New Delhi | July 10, 2025 09:47 IST
4 min read
Vehicles including an electric rickshaw are seen stuck in a flood-like situation, while two-wheeler riders struggle to push their bikes through the inundated streets (Image source: @divya_gandotra/X)

Heavy rain lashed the Delhi-NCR region on Wednesday evening, leading to severe waterlogging in parts of the national capital and Gurgaon. Videos showing flooded roads, stranded vehicles and residents wading through knee-deep water have gone viral on social media.

In one such clip, vehicles, including an electric rickshaw, are seen stuck in a flood-like situation, while two-wheeler riders struggle to push their bikes through the inundated streets.

Sharing a video from Gurgaon‚Äôs Golf Course Road, journalist Sumedha Sharma wrote, ‚ÄúFor the unversed, this is the very road where apartments are sold for over 100 crores. #GurgaonRains turns Golf Course Road into a river. Venice vibes and doorstep thrill surely deserve this price. The #LuxuryLiving hub.‚Äù

For the unversed this is very road where apartments are sold for over 100 crores. #GurgaonRains turns Golf course road into river. Venice vibes and door step thrill surely deserves this price. The #LuxuryLiving hub #Gurgaon #Gurugram #GurugramRains #gurugramrain pic.twitter.com/rcpwlcmfGl

‚Äî Sumedha Sharma (@sumedhasharma86) July 9, 2025

Another video shows a car stuck in a waterlogged stretch as a group of people attempt to move it. Slamming the authorities, X user Divya Gandotra Tandon wrote. ‚ÄúMiddle-class Indians pay:- Income Tax: up to 30% (plus cess)- GST: 5% to 28% on goods/services- Petrol/Diesel Tax: ~50% of the fuel price is tax (central + state)- Road Tax: one-time, varies by state (up to 10-12% of vehicle value)- Property Tax: paid annually to municipal bodies ‚Äì Toll Tax, Cess, Swachh Bharat, etc. and THIS is what we get? This is Gurgaon on 9th July, 9:30 PM flooded like a swimming pool. Where does our money go? No drainage, no planning, no accountability.‚Äù

Middle-class Indians pay:
‚Äì Income Tax: up to 30% (plus cess)
‚Äì GST: 5% to 28% on goods/services
‚Äì Petrol/Diesel Tax: ~50% of the fuel price is tax (central + state)
‚Äì Road Tax: one-time, varies by state (up to 10-12% of vehicle value)
‚Äì Property Tax: paid annually to municipal‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/hn4T1mgTSq

‚Äî Divya Gandotra Tandon (@divya_gandotra) July 10, 2025

Watch viral videos here:

Waterlogging and traffic disruptions were reported from several key areas, including Arvind Marg, GK Marg, Rail Bhawan, Akshardham, Ashram, ITO, Pul Prahladpur, MB Road, MG Road, Old Rohtak Road, Shadipur, Madhuban Chowk, and National Highway 8.

According to the India Meteorological Department (IMD), ‚ÄúAn eastward-moving cloud cluster is likely to cause moderate rainfall at most places, with heavy rainfall at isolated locations, accompanied by thunderstorms, lightning, and strong winds gusting up to 50 kmph during the next two hours.‚Äù

Shallow earthquake of magnitude 4.4 jolts Delhi-NCR
Cities17 min ago

A relatively mild earthquake of magnitude 4.4 jolted Delhi and nearby areas on Thursday morning. The earthquake originated around Jhajjar in Haryana and was felt across the National Capital Region. The National Centre of Seismology said the earthquake was shallow and originated about 10 km below the earth‚Äôs surface.
